Garangolm.hunter_notes:
Garangolm will reinforce their arms by covering them in elements. When their arms are in this state, continuously attacking the elemental covering will eventually break it off, toppling the beast. Focus your assault on their arms as soon as they're covered!Garangolm attack using their fists, slamming them in front of them. They are also capable of digging into the ground and throwing rocks as projectiles. When a Garangolm enrages, they will dig both their fists into the ground, coating their right arm with molten rocks and their left arms with mossy rocks. In this state, slams from their arms create elemental bursts, with their right arm inflicting Fireblight and leaving behind dust that inflicts Blastblight, while their left arm inflicts Waterblight. Garangolm are also capable of using their right arm to rocket jump across the Area to reposition. Damaging one of their fists enough will destroy the rocks on both and topple the monster.
When on low health, Garangolm will also armour their face when entering enrage, allowing them to perform deadlier attacks involving steam-based explosions. If the armour on their face or arms is not broken by the time their enrage finishes, they will unearth a large boulder from the ground before punching it, causing it to explode and reverting them to an armourless state.
Garangolm.sightings: Garangolm is found in the Flooded Forest and the Citadel.
Garangolm.characteristics: A monster characterized by its massive and rigid body. Garangolm are generally placid, living in regions with fertile soil. Their sap-like fluids can promote plant growth, forging a symbiotic relationship with flora that grows in their bodies. They can also use that sap to harden plants or the surrounding soil outfitting their bodies and enhancing their attacks.Garangolm will reinforce their arms by covering them in elements. When their arms are in this state, continuously attacking the elemental covering will eventually break it off, toppling the beast. Focus your assault on their arms as soon as they're covered!

Goss Harag.hunter_notes:
In hitting the accumulated frost on its forelegs, a hunter risks being afflicted with iceblight, but is rewarded by the creature being toppled when the frost is shattered. Areas that appear red when the creature is angry are the most susceptible, so focus your efforts there!In their normal state, Goss Harag primarily attacks with their forelegs, either by scratching with them or punching with them.
When the monster enraged, they will proceed to fire off 2 ice beams before forming an ice blade on their right arm (+ an ice club on their left in High Rank onwards). This blade extends the range of their physical attacks with their arms and causes these attacks to inflict Iceblight. Eventually Goss Harag will throw 3 ice shuriken forward, followed by both weapons they have present, exiting their enrage in the process. Damaging one of their ice blades enough will cause them both to shatter, toppling them.
At low enough health, Goss Harag will instead form a twin pair of blades. In Master Rank, to form these blades, they will perform a quick dash, ending by slashing them in front of them.
Goss Harag.sightings: Goss Harag is found in the Frost Islands and the Citadel.
Goss Harag.characteristics: A monster native to ice-cold climates. Covered in fur so thick it keeps out the harsh frost, it roams the snowy plains in search of prey. It can inhale the cold air to freeze its own bodily fluids and then spit on them to create icy blades in its arms. When riled up, the Goss Harag turns red and becomes exceedingly dangerous.In hitting the accumulated frost on its forelegs, a hunter risks being afflicted with iceblight, but is rewarded by the creature being toppled when the frost is shattered. Areas that appear red when the creature is angry are the most susceptible, so focus your efforts there!

Lagombi.hunter_notes: A Lagombi has very sensitive hearing, and Sonic Bombs will cause it to flinch in pain. Time a well-aimed throw for when it's sliding around, and you may topple it. When enraged, however, Sonic Bombs have no effect on it.Lagombi mainly attacks by sliding across the snow on their belly and by throwing snowballs at the hunter that leave behind movement-restricting piles of snow. Lagombi also posses sensitive hearing, resulting in them being briefly stunned if hit with a Sonic Bomb. If hit with a Sonic bomb while sliding on their belly, the Lagombi will be toppled.
Lagombi.sightings: Lagombi is found in the Frost Islands and the Citadel.
Lagombi.characteristics:
Fanged, long-eared beasts whose warm pelts and thick layers of fat help them survive in cold climates. Though mainly herbivores, Lagombi occasionally make use of their exceptional hearing and ability to glide on ice to sneak up on prey.A Lagombi has very sensitive hearing, and Sonic Bombs will cause it to flinch in pain. Time a well-aimed throw for when it's sliding around, and you may topple it. When enraged, however, Sonic Bombs have no effect on it.A medium-sized fanged beast, Lagombi has a body frame similar to its relative Arzuros, albeit more reminiscent of a giant rabbit. Its head sports a pair of long and highly sensitive ears (which gives them a weakness to loud noises), as well as a beak-like structure over the mouth, facilitating the process of picking up food. It is covered from head to toe in white fur and a thick, subcutaneous layer of fat, making it highly adapted to frigid environments.
The belly of a Lagombi is not furry, but rather covered with an elastic plastron. Said plastron is lined with hardened ridges that serve to cut and shear the snow, allowing for fast, stable and surprisingly silent movement. By pouncing and landing onto the plastron with momentum, Lagombi can slide around the ground at high speeds. Lagombi plastrons become polished over many years of use, eventually turning into a tough and smooth armor shell.[3]
Lagombi's claws have a unique curvature to them, specialized for gripping and stabbing into the snow. While sliding, Lagombi can dig these claws into the snow to perform emergency brakes and tight turns. Like Arzuros, it grows a shell bracer—though not as developed or spiky—that enhances the claws' durability. Due to their constant exposure to the cold, Lagombi claws are often covered in a thin layer of permanent frost.[4] This causes wounds created by these claws to freeze over instantly, giving the beast an additional offensive ability.[5][6]
Given how well the claws can handle massive amounts of snow, Lagombi can dig its hands into the ground and launch large snowballs at its enemies, slowing them down and freezing them. Meanwhile, the legs are highly muscular, allowing Lagombi to leap into the air and come crashing down violently, or quickly pounce, allowing it to reposition with a slide at rapid pace.
Lagombi.behavior: Lagombi are generally herbivorous, feeding on the scarce nuts and plants that they find in their frigid homelands. They can however eat meat and will actively hunt prey on rare occassions.[7] Using their superior sense of hearing, Lagombi track prey across the snowy tundras. By not relying on their eyes, these beasts completely avoid the adverse effect on vision that the glaring sunlight reflected by snow usually has on wanderers in the frost, while also being less affected by blinding blizzards. Additionally, a Lagombi sliding on its plastron is suprisingly silent, increasing the beast's stealth significantly. Thus, Lagombi hunt by identifying prey from afar through sound and then sneaking up rapidly on it by sliding.[1]

Rajang.hunter_notes:
A Rajang is most dangerous when its arms are powered up, allowing it to even destroy Shock Traps. Attack its tail to remove this effect. In its regular state, it will also avoid Pitfall Traps. It will immediately attack anything that invades its territory, so watch your step.Rajang mainly attack with their fists, rapidly punching at their opponent. They are also capable of firing of beams of energy and spitting out blasts of thunder.
When a Rajang enrages, they will leap backwards with their fur turning golden. After enough time in their enrage state, Rajang will rear up on their hindlegs and roar, knocking away anyone too close and causing them to enter Rampage Mode. In this state, Rajang’s arms harden considerably, causing most attacks to bounce and for attacks with their arms to deal more damage. Damaging their tail enough in this state will force them to exit their enrage. In High Rank, this will topple them, but in Master Rank it merely flinches them.
In High Rank, Rajang can appear as an invader, spawning asleep in a specific Area of the map.
Rajang.sightings: Rajang can be found in every locale.
Rajang.characteristics: An ultra-aggressive creature that is rarely sighted and seldom survived. Those that have survived report that it exhibits a strange attack. Rajang are said to be loners, and this isolated life has made it difficult to pin down its territorial leanings. When angered, part of its pelt turns a golden color.A Rajang is most dangerous when its arms are powered up, allowing it to even destroy Shock Traps. Attack its tail to remove this effect. In its regular state, it will also avoid Pitfall Traps. It will immediately attack anything that invades its territory, so watch your step.

Furious Rajang.hunter_notes:
Since Furious Rajang lack a tail, you'll need to focus your attention on attacking their head to knock them out of rampage mode. Keep in mind that Furious Rajang use a lot of powerful restraining attacks, so if you get clobbered, use Wirefall to quickly recover and retreat.Furious attack similarly to Rajang, with rapid punches and beams of energy. Furious is also capable of plunging their arms into the ground, sending off lightning faults in front of them.
While Furious is enraged, eventually they will rear up on their hindlegs and roar, knocking away anyone too close and causing them to enter Rampage Mode. In this state, Furious’ arms harden considerably, causing most attacks to bounce and they are capable of following up more of their attacks with lightning faults. Additionally, they gain access to some of their strongest attacks, such as following up a missed pin attack with them picking up a boulder and throwing it forward, the effects of which vary with the terrain. Damaging their head enough in this state will force them to exit their enrage and topple them.
Furious Rajang.sightings: Furious Rajang can be found in any locale.
Furious Rajang.characteristics: Furious Rajang are Rajang variants that are covered in golden fur. Normally Rajang return to their black-furred state after being agitated for a time to conserve energy, but these beasts have lost the ability to curb their anger. Outclassing the standard Rajang's attack power, they assault with seething rage. At the apex of their fury they become enraged and turn into destructive demons with electrified manes.Since Furious Rajang lack a tail, you'll need to focus your attention on attacking their head to knock them out of rampage mode. Keep in mind that Furious Rajang use a lot of powerful restraining attacks, so if you get clobbered, use Wirefall to quickly recover and retreat.

Volvidon.hunter_notes: The toxin that Volvidon spit out can paralyze on contact. You'll also want to carry some Deodorant, as the gas they emit can cover you in a stench so powerful that it makes it impossible to stomach anything.Volvidon attack by curling into a ball, where they either roll forward or slam themself into the ground. They will also utilize their long, whip-like tongue as well as various status ailments, such as stench-inducing gas or paralyzing spit. While rolling, if a hunter is able to hit and flinch them, the Volvidon will be knocked back and toppled.
Volvidon.sightings: Volvidon is found in the Sandy Plains, Lava Caverns and the Citadel.
Volvidon.characteristics:
Fanged beasts with thick red carapaces that are resistant to lava. Their rounded bodies are perfect for rolling across hot surfaces, and their long tongues are ideal for capturing insect prey. Their saliva emits a paralyzing toxin that should be avoided.The toxin that Volvidon spit out can paralyze on contact. You'll also want to carry some Deodorant, as the gas they emit can cover you in a stench so powerful that it makes it impossible to stomach anything.Volvidon is a medium-sized monster, with the same basic body plan as its close relatives, Arzuros and Lagombi. However, it displays significant physiological differences beyond that. For one, its face is flat and long, and the hands only have four fingers—as opposed to five on both of its rlatives—with the second finger and claw being abnormally large, often compared to a trowel. Most intriguingly, its body is covered not in fur, but in a red shell.
This segmented armor is thick and sturdy, yet elastic, granting the beast high defense with virtually no downsides to its mobility. The shell is also supremely heat-resistant, able to withstand magma for a short while.[3] The resilience of this material is so well-developed that Volvidon shells are noted by blacksmiths to be extremely difficult to work with.[4] By curling its body, the segments on Volvidon's shell overlap such that they turn the creature's body into an armored ball. The elasticity of the shell is also capable of redistributing force. Thus, by strategically contracting and expanding the muscles under it, Volvidon can bounce while rolled up, gathering momentum and moving at high speeds.
Another trait that makes Volvidon stand out from its close relatives is its tongue, which is prehensile and can extend to a total length of nearly 20 meters. While this adaptation seems to have emerged for feeding purposes, it can also serve as a weapon: During combat, Volvidon may use its long tongue as a whip, striking foes from afar with wide-ranging attacks.
Many of the insects Volvidon devours, such as Bnahabra, contain various paralytic poisons. When feeding, these poisons are stored in its paralysis sac, which connects to its saliva glands.[5][1]  By mixing these compounds in its mouth, Volvidon can spit globules of concentrated paralysis venom, which is absorbed by the skin of whoever gets splashed by it. Furthermore, when digesting the shells of insects, the monster's gut produces various foul gases, which get stored in a layer under its skin. When necessary, Volvidon can expel these gases from the gaps between its shell segments, dowsing any unlucky enemy in a pungent cloud of odor.
Volvidon.behavior: Volvidon are omnivorous, but have a strong preference for insects. It can infiltrate Altaroth nests and pull them out of their tunnels, or it can swipe Bnahabra straight out of the air using its long tongue.[1]

Dodogama.hunter_notes: Dodogama primarily attacks by scooping their jaws along the ground. As they do this, they pick up rocks within their mouth causing it to glow, which they can fire off as single shots or as large barrages. However, they can only shoot a limited number before their supply is depleted, with a single barrage being enough to do so. Damaging their head enough can force Dodogama to drop their rocks. In Master Rank, Dodogama is capable of storing more rocks in their mouth, causing it to glow even brighter.
Dodogama.sightings: Dodogama is found primarily in the Elder's Recess. They can also be found in the Volcanic Region of the Guiding Lands.
Dodogama.characteristics: A monster that devours rock as its primary diet. The Crystals it devours mix with its saliva to produce explosive minerals that it can spit at its enemies.
Dodogama.useful_information: Useful Information: Dodogama collects explosive materials in its mouth, but doing so weakens its massive jaw. Causing the minerals to detonate while they're still in Dodogama's mouth will create a great opening for attack.

Great Girros.hunter_notes: Great Girros primarily attacks by biting towards their target, with each bite having a chance to Paralyse. They can also spit out a paralyzing venom. Great Girros typically fights alongside a horde of smaller Girros, which will typically rush into the zone they are in to assist. By rattling their gills, they are capable of commanding all Girros in the area to lunge at the hunter.
Great Girros.sightings: Great Girros is found primarily in the Rotten Vale. They can also be found in the Rotten region of the Guiding Lands.
Great Girros.characteristics: A monster that scavenges for meals dropped from the Coral Highlands. It acts as the alpha leader of a Girros pack, and sports giant fangs that paralyze its prey.
Great Girros.useful_information: Useful Information: Taking down lesser Girros will make the rest of the pack scatter, and should be a top priority. Breaking the fangs of a Great Girros will make its paralyzing agent much weaker.

Great Jagras.hunter_notes: Great Jagras primarily attacks by biting towards their target. Periodically, Great Jagras will sniff at the ground before running towards the nearest Herbivore and swallowing them whole, causing their belly to inflate. In this state, their attacks are slower but more damaging, gaining the ability to spew out meat. Eventually, Great Jagras will fully regurgitate their meal, returning to their slim state. Damaging their belly enough will cause them to topple, slowing regurgitating as they return to normal.
Great Jagras.sightings: Great Jagras is found primarily in the Ancient Forest. They can also be found in the Forest region of the Guiding Lands.
Great Jagras.characteristics: The pack leader of the Jagras. When hungry, Great Jagras are known to attack monsters even stronger than themselves. It balloons to unbelievable proportions after swallowing prey.
Great Jagras.useful_information: Useful Information: Even after a giant meal, a Great Jagras can use its expanded stomach to attack unsuspecting hunters. Aim for its belly to force it to vomit out its prey and significantly weaken it.

Lunagaron.hunter_notes:
Lunagaron have different attacks depending on their stance. They also use ice attacks, so raising your ice resistance should give you an edge. Lunagaron are extremely agile when on all fours, so try not to lose track of them. When covered in ice, a continuous assault will not only result in shattering the covering but will also topple the beast. Mind your positioning when powerful attacks are incoming.Lunagaron begins the fight as a quadruped, primarily attacking by biting and rushing forward towards their target. Periodically, Lunagaron will release ice gas around themself, forming a layer of ice armour on their body. After performing this attack twice, Lunagaron will gain the ability to rear up on his hindlegs.
While on their hindlegs, Lunagaron primarily attacks with their claws, either swiping them in front of them or dragging them along the ground. While armoured, Lunagaron will freely transition between attacking on all fours and attacking on their hindlegs, frequently combo-ing attacks from the two stances together. Damaging their ice armour enough will cause it to shatter, toppling the monster and reverting them to a fully quadrupedal stance.
Lunagaron.sightings: Lunagaron is found in the Shrine Ruins, Frost Islands, the Citadel  and Jungle.
Lunagaron.characteristics: Lunagaron have an organ that chills the air they inhale, circulating it throughout their body in a unique form of thermoregulation. They can travel long distances and endure environmental changes, allowing them to occupy a wide range of habitats. They usually walk on all fours, but can stand on two legs by shutting down their cooling mechanism, spiking their body temp to expand their muscles.Lunagaron have different attacks depending on their stance. They also use ice attacks, so raising your ice resistance should give you an edge. Lunagaron are extremely agile when on all fours, so try not to lose track of them. When covered in ice, a continuous assault will not only result in shattering the covering but will also topple the beast. Mind your positioning when powerful attacks are incoming.

Magnamalo.hunter_notes:
The majority of Magnamalo's attacks involve its hellfire. If you become afflicted with hellfireblight, Wiredash to rid yourself of this status. You can counter its attacks by focusing on parts of its body that are emitting hellfire. If you can manage to ignite any of the vapor with your attacks, you can deal massive damage.Magnamalo mainly attacks with precise stabs from their spear-like tail, biting or by slamming their claws down. They are also able to fire off the hellfire they produce both as fireballs or as clouds.
Magnamalo begins the fight with hellfire coating their head and tail, with the position of the hellfire switching when the monster enrages. After taking enough damage, they will create an explosion around themself when enraging, coating all their body parts in hellfire. While their body parts are coated in hellfire, their physical attacks become able to inflict Hellfireblight. While their head is coated, Magnamalo is capable of performing pin attacks. While their arms are coated, they are capable of performing rocket boosts both as attacks and to reposition around the hunter. While their tail is coated, they can fire multiple hell-fireballs at once and release hellfire from their tail as a large blast. Damaging any part covered in hellfire enough will return it to normal.
Periodically in the fight, Magnamalo will rear up on their hindlegs while releasing hellfire clouds around them. At first, this coats hellfire onto their back, with the second performance causing all their hellfire to turn pink. Leaving them in this state too long will cause them to perform a super-attack: running around the zone releasing hellfire clouds before rocket diving towards the hunter. Damaging any part coated in pink hellfire enough, however, will dissipate all the hellfire on the monster and topple them.
When engaged with a turf with Aknosom, Barioth, Rathalos or Bazelgeuse, they will aim their final divebomb towards any hunter present in the Area.
Magnamalo.sightings: Magnamalo is found in the Shrine Ruins, Frost Islands and the Lava Caverns.
Magnamalo.characteristics:
A monster with a carapace like tempered steel armor. The vapor around it is actually the expelling of trapped gases from the hordes of monsters Magnamalo has consumed. This has earned it the moniker "Wyvern of Malice." Its shrouded swings can inflict hellfireblight, which causes one to combust either spontaneously or when hit. Use aThe majority of Magnamalo's attacks involve its hellfire. If you become afflicted with hellfireblight, Wiredash to rid yourself of this status. You can counter its attacks by focusing on parts of its body that are emitting hellfire. If you can manage to ignite any of the vapor with your attacks, you can deal massive damage.Magnamalo is a tigrine Fanged Wyvern with a purple carapace with the appearance and strength of plate armor, along with numerous tan, bony protrusions all around its body, notably a set of scutes on its back that are normally folded up and only extend when enraged to allow more Hellfire to flow from its back vents. These scutes are covered in nicks and cracks from countless battles in virtually all Magnamalo.[3] It has a pair of intricate horns on its head, enlarged claws on its forearms that have grown to resemble blades,[4] and a long tail tipped with a bony point resembling a spear tip. Its arm blades, fangs, and tail tip can fold in and out at will, with its tail being able to unfold into a cross shape when hunting prey.[5] Its underbelly is red and less armored, with these red scales also filling in the gaps in its carapace to allow it to move properly.
Magnamalo hunts prey using the various "weapons" on its body, then processes the bones of consumed prey into a gaseous, explosive purple substance known as "Hellfire", which is first condensed in the body as solid prisms.[6] When needed, a Magnamalo expels gaseous Hellfire from small vents on its arms, tail, mouth, and back,[1] engulfing its body in ghostly purple flames and producing a characteristic eerie howling sound. It uses this volatile gas to hunt by spreading explosive clouds, shooting blasts of flame, creating explosions with its physical blows, and propelling itself with miniature explosions, the last of which allows it to grapple and bring down flying prey. The longer its Hellfire burns for, the more volatile and pink it turns.
Inside the body, Magnamalo grow mysterious purple orbs that seem to glow with the light of lost souls.[7] It is unknown if this is at all related to its Hellfire.
Because of the high metabolism required to sustain its Hellfire, it can quickly regain its vitality and recover from injury given enough food nearby.[8] However, Magnamalo's horns only grow once in its life and can never be regrown if broken.[1]
Magnamalo.behavior:
Due to the high metabolic demand required to sustain its Hellfire at a healthy level, Magnamalo is a highly aggressive and belligerent predator that will attempt to attack nearly anything that could be seen as prey, regardless of its strength or size. Because of this, it will often be found in locales where large groups of monsters gather, such as the Rampage that regularly threatens Kamura Village.
Male Magnamalo typically defend and expand large territories where they provide for multiple female mates and their young, and may come into competition with other males for territory and/or mating rights. The quality and size of a Magnamalo's horns and carapace are known factors for sexual selection, and a male Magnamalo whose horns are broken will be unable to mate for the rest of its life.[1] If this occurs, the Magnamalo will forgo mating and protecting its carapace in favor of recklessly hunting stronger prey to increase its strength and the power of its Hellfire, with the most tenacious and extreme individuals potentially developing into Scorned Magnamalo.[9]

Scorned Magnamalo.hunter_notes:
When these variants concentrate their Hellfire, they can unleash powerful attacks but also become more susceptible to damage if the Hellfire on their body is detonated. Press the attack further to send them into the Raging Hellfire state. But beware of powerful attacks from the body parts infused with Hellfire.Scorned attacks in a similar fashion to Magnamalo, utilising their spear-like tail and their hellfire-based projectiles. Unlike regular Magnamalo, Scorned will also frequently use the blades on their arms to attack with. Scorned Magnamalo, upon spotting the hunter, will immediately perform Magnamalo’s super attack.
Scorned starts the fight with all their body parts already coated in hellfire, causing most of their physical attack to inflict Hellfireblight. After receiving enough damage, Scorned will divert all their hellfire to their arm-blades, powering them up and allowing them to create a large burst of hellfire using them. Damaging their arms enough will cause their hellfire to re-spread across their entire body, toppling them.
On low enough health, Scorned will rear up before releasing a burst of dragon energy around them, entering an enhanced version of their powered-up self. In this state, they can perform their hellfire blade-burst twice in a row and follow-up their hellfire blasts from their tail with a sweeping blast of dragon energy.
Scorned Magnamalo.sightings: Scorned Magnamalo is found in the Shrine Ruins, Flooded Forest, Lava Caverns and the Citadel.
Scorned Magnamalo.characteristics:
A Magnamalo variant that achieves an even more twisted, malevolent form. Filled with hatred, they are known as "Scorned Magnamalo." Shrouded in Hellfire at all times, they also boast larger arm blades and harder armor plating. During battles, they have been spotted focusing their Hellfire and swinging it like a blade.When these variants concentrate their Hellfire, they can unleash powerful attacks but also become more susceptible to damage if the Hellfire on their body is detonated. Press the attack further to send them into the Raging Hellfire state. But beware of powerful attacks from the body parts infused with Hellfire.Scorned Magnamalo broadly resembles regular Magnamalo, with the most notable differences being its much larger, serrated back shells and arm blades. It is missing an eye and horn compared to normal specimen, has noticeably larger fangs, and is covered in faintly glowing red scars. Its entire body is darker in coloration and shrouded in pink Hellfire at all times, even when not in combat. It is also entirely covered in bruises and scratches, down to even its individual scales.[3]
Scorned Magnamalo is able to concentrate its Hellfire on specific parts of its body. Although Hellfire is normally present across its whole body, it will unfold its arm blades and focus all of its Hellfire into them once enraged, extinguishing its back and tail. If further angered, it will reignite its tail and unfold the shells on its back.
Scorned Magnamalo is much stronger than a normal Magnamalo, having gained more mastery over their Hellfire and enhanced physicality, particularly a new mastery of its arm blades. The Hellfire produced by a Scorned Magnamalo is also more condensed and thus more explosive and violent.[4] It unleashes extremely violent attacks that cover a wide area with explosions, such as wielding its arm blades to perform multiple slashing attacks in succession, or concentrating its Hellfire to produce pressurized blasts akin to swinging a blade of flame. When sufficiently enraged, they can enter a "Raging Hellfire State" where their Hellfire becomes red and infused with dragon element, allowing it to inflict dragonblight.[5] The one eye of a Scorned Magnamalo has an eerie glow that is said to never fade even after being removed from the wyvern's socket.[6]
Scorned Magnamalo.behavior:
A Scorned Magnamalo is said to come to be when a male Magnamalo has its horns broken for any reason, rendering it undesirable for females and unable to mate for the rest of its life. As a result, the Magnamalo forgoes mating and focuses entirely on hunting prey, recklessly facing and devouring increasingly dangerous foes to accumulate power and bolster its Hellfire. If the Magnamalo survives for long enough, it can undergo gradual morphological changes that turn it into a Scorned Magnamalo.
Being "scorned" by their kind and a lifetime of battle scars has caused Scorned Magnamalo to become even more aggressive than usual, to the point where onlookers describe it as a malevolent demon filled with hatred. It ruthlessly attacks anything that approaches its territory, and will actively seek out powerful foes to battle and devour, even Elder Dragons.[4] Because it no longer needs to protect its horns and armor, it is especially reckless, battling with no regard for its own safety.

Odogaron.hunter_notes:
Odogaron are very nimble monsters, attacking primarily by lunging at the hunter and swiping at them with their claws, which can inflict Bleeding. Odogaron are also very adept at combo-ing their various attacks together.
Odogaron, upon eating meat, will enter a special enrage state as their body begins to glow. In this state, they are able to perform their enraged combos as well as being able to bite in a wider radius. However, Odogaron will always exit this state exhausted. While in Master Rank, Odogaron begins the fight in this state, with them typically attempting to re-enter as soon as they exit it.
If a Legiana corpse falls into the Rotten Vale, Odogaron, will attempt to drag it back to their nest in Area 13.
Odogaron.sightings: Odogaron is found in the Coral Highlands and the Rotten Vale. They can also be found in the Rotten region of the Guiding Lands from level 2 onwards and the Coral region from level 3 onwards.
Odogaron.characteristics:
A terrifying monster that scours the Rotten Vale for carrion. Its highly aggressive nature means that anything, be it monster or man, is a potential meal.Odogaron are terrifying fanged wyvern that are covered in a highly textured, red skin. Their bodies are slender, displaying near zero fat tissue and instead being highly muscular and defined.[3] The heads of Odogaron end in long snouts, with multiple rows of teeth visible at all times. The top and bottom canine teeth are notably enlarged. The jaw and neck muscles of Odogaron are deceptively powerful, allowing this species to carry large flying wyvern such as Legiana in their mouths.[6]
Odogaron eyes are a dull blue color and never close. That is because they do not have eyelids. Instead, the entire eyeball is covered in a thick cornea that is adapted to withstand the effects of the Effluvium found in the places Odogaron inhabit. This makes the eyesight of the wyvern quite poor, enabling it only to differentiate between light and dark.[7] This however does not pose much of a problem - in the dimly lit Rotten Vale, eyesight is not a particularly useful sense to begin with.[8] Additionally, this reduced eyesight makes Odogaron unaffected by the flashes of light produced by monsters such as the Tzitzi-Ya-Ku, which they might encounter while hunting.
To compensate for their weak eyes, Odogaron have an extremely well developed sense of smell,[9] which can be further enhanced by widening their large and flexible nostrils.[8] Armed with their strong olfactory skill, Odogaron can easily distinguish between the different smells of corpses, identifying fresh ones and locking onto various tracks, especially favoring the smell of blood.[8]
A very notable physiological feature of Odogaron are their unique claw structures. Odogaron posses two sets of claws on their feet: Four walking claws, which are stuff and protrude from the knuckles, sitting on top of hard round pads which make contact with the ground. In addition to this set, Odogaron have six battle claws that usually remain folded upwards towards the ankle. Most of the time, the battle claws remain retracted, which allows Odogaron to walk without making any sound. When prey is spotted, Odogaron extend their battle claws downwards, which are long and serrated. By slashing at targets with these claws, Odogaron can create brutal gashes that bleed profusely.[9]
As they do not tend to store fat, Odogaron need near constant calorie input to survive. Should an Odogaron eat after a long period of fasting, it might enter a special state called the Full-body Flush. During this state, the body of the wyvern pulsates with a red glow and steam erupts from its mouth. Odogaron are also significantly more aggressive during this state. The mechanisms behind the Full-body Flush are not entirely understood yet, but it is believed that it is a result of the wyvern's body temperature suddenly spiking as digestion kicks in, combined with the Odogaron's excitement at finally being able to eat again.[9]
The tails of Odogaron are distinguishable by their numerous hard white protrusions at the tip. These are hardened veils of skin, which grow and develop over the wyvern's lifetime. Juvenile Odogaron mostly lack them, growing them as they mature. In fact, these protrusions never stop growing, and can even allow an Odogaron to regrow some length of its tail after it has been severed.[8]
Odogaron.behavior:
Odogaron are entirely endemic to the New World and have thus far never been sighted anywhere else. They inhabit the Rotten Vale and the Guiding Lands, where they are known to be brutal predators and scavengers, acting purely on a single-minded instinct to kill and feed, earning themselves the nickname "Cruel Claw".[10] Perfectly adapted to the corpse heap of the new continent, Odogaron sniff out the freshest corpses before any other scavenger can even think of claiming them.[8]
Odogaron will also actively hunt, overwhelming prey with their superior speed and agility. One brutal tactic they employ is to lacerate their target with their battle claws early on, condemning them to a slow death by blood loss - and even if they should get away, the nose of the Odogaron can track the scent of their blood all the way to their final breath.[8] While it usually prowls the Rotten Vale, it has been observed venturing as far as the Coral Highlands to secure a meal.[3]
Once they have secured a kill, Odogaron will usually not immediately feast on, instead carrying it all the way back to their nest in the Vale. They do so by utilizing a network of tunnels that permeate the Vale, allowing Odogaron to quickly travel across the region while protecting their bounty. Once they arrive at their nests, Odogaron indulge in one of their more eccentric behaviors - they add their kill to a massive stockpile of meat. While storage like this makes sense for a creature with such a demanding metabolism, it has also been suggested that Odogaron intentionally dry age meat this way, as they seem to prefer the taste of carrion after it has sat around in a dry pile for some time.[3]
Odogaron are also known to often carry a slab of meat with them while patrolling their habitats. This appears to be an insurance policy to have a quick bite if hunger sets in[3] and enter into the Full-body Flush at will for a quick power boost during challenging encounters.[9]
Odogaron.useful_information: Useful Information: Odogaron's nasty claws cause heavy bleeding and should be avoided at all costs. use meat to lure it into traps, stagger it, or coerce it into bouts of rage to tire it out and make it easier to deal with.

Ebony Odogaron.hunter_notes:
Much like Odogaron, Ebony are highly agile monsters that attack by biting and swiping with their claws. Ebony begins the fight charged with dragon energy, causing their bites to inflict Dragon element damage and giving them the ability to spit Dragon-infused meat as projectiles, often done so mid-combo. If enough elemental damage is dealt to Ebony's head, the monster will be toppled and their empowered state removed. Ebony's head can similarly only be broken with elemental damage. Ebony re-enters their empowered state whenever they eat.
At the start of the fight, Ebony spawns carrying a piece of meat in their mouth. Whenever they move between zones, Ebony will always fetch that meat before leaving. After eating it, Ebony can create new pieces of meat by killing and eating from Small Monsters such as Raphinos.
Ebony Odogaron.sightings: Ebony Odogaron can be found in any locales. They can be found in any region of the Guiding Lands from level 3 onwards.
Ebony Odogaron.characteristics: This Odogaron subspecies is forever on the prowl for its next meal, and is often seeing carrying fresh kills in its mouth. Reports indicate it goes into a frenzy upon eating.
Ebony Odogaron.useful_information: Useful Information: When frenzied, it uses dragon elemental attacks, but hunters can hit its head with their own elemental attacks to calm it. The key to success is to keep it from feeding.

Tobi-Kadachi.hunter_notes:
Characteristics: A fanged wyvern that flies among the treetops. Its penchant to brush against the ground and the trees as it moves around builds up static electricity within its fur. This action allows it to reach a charged state-identified by its glowing fur-in which its head and tail attacks are said to be particularly lethal. Always keep the Tobi-Kadachi in your sights to avoid being ambushed from behind. The key to defeating this monster is to immobilize it and prevent it from reaching a charged state. If you can make use of endemic life to afflict it with waterblight, it'll no longer be able to charge itself up.
Threat Level: ★★★★★Tobi-Kadachi attack primarily by swiping or slamming their large tail around themself, often gliding into the air beforehand, though they are also capable of performing lunging bites. Tobi-Kadachi are also capable of clinging to walls, which they can leap off to attack from.
As Tobi-Kadachi attack, they gradually build up a static charge in their fur, signalled by them growling. Charge is built up faster while clinging to a wall. Eventually, Tobi-Kadachi will roar and enter a charged state, causing their physical attacks with their tail to inflict Thunderblight. Damaging them enough will revert them back to their regular state. Alternatively, their charge can also be dampened by throwing a Mudbeetle at them.
Tobi-Kadachi.sightings: Tobi-Kadachi is found in the Shrine Ruins, Flooded Forest and Jungle.
Tobi-Kadachi.characteristics:
A fanged wyvern that flies among the treetops. Its penchant to brush against the ground and the trees as it moves around builds up static electricity within its fur. This action allows it to reach a charged state-identified by its glowing fur-in which its head and tail attacks are said to be particularly lethal.Characteristics: A fanged wyvern that flies among the treetops. Its penchant to brush against the ground and the trees as it moves around builds up static electricity within its fur. This action allows it to reach a charged state-identified by its glowing fur-in which its head and tail attacks are said to be particularly lethal. Always keep the Tobi-Kadachi in your sights to avoid being ambushed from behind. The key to defeating this monster is to immobilize it and prevent it from reaching a charged state. If you can make use of endemic life to afflict it with waterblight, it'll no longer be able to charge itself up.
Threat Level: ★★★★★

Viper Tobi-Kadachi.hunter_notes:
Viper Tobi-Kadachi, primarily attacks by swiping and slamming with their large tail, which inflicts Poison, and by lunging and biting at the hunter, which inflicting Paralysis. They are also capable of briefly gliding into the air, with them additionally being able to reposition in the air before attacking. Viper can also fire off poisonous quills from their tail.
While poisoned, getting hit by a second move from Viper that would inflict Poison upgrades said poison to Noxious Poison.
Viper Tobi-Kadachi.sightings: Viper Tobi-Kadachi is found primarily in the Hoarfrost Reach. They can also be found in the Frozen region of the Guiding Lands.
Viper Tobi-Kadachi.characteristics: The tail of this subspecies secretes a toxin while its fangs paralyze prey. It can also glide without climbing trees.
Viper Tobi-Kadachi.useful_information: Useful Information: Its agility is its greatest weapon, but also makes it prone to exhaustion. When tired, it grows drastically less mobile. Focus attacks on its soft parts to tucker it out quickly.

Zinogre.hunter_notes:
Characteristics: Fanged wyverns whose bodies are streaked with electricity. Sharp claws and strong limbs allow them to thrive in mountainous terrain. During hunts, they gather numerous Thunderbugs to boost their power and enter a supercharged state. In their supercharged states, Zinogre not only have different attack patterns but also become faster, hit harder, and gain immunity to Shock Traps. Staggering them, however, may knock them out of this state.
Threat Level: ★★★★★★Zinogre attack primarily by slamming either their tail or their forelimbs, both of which can be performed after a headbutt. They can send off the Fulgurbugs gathered in their back as curving projectiles. Zinogre’s movement is very fluid, with them being capable of combo-ing several of their different attacks together.
Periodically during the fight, Zinogre will begin howling into the air to call more Thunderbugs to their back, eventually emitting a pulse of thunder around them as they enter a charged state. In this state, most of Zinogre’s physical attacks become imbued with Thunder element, as well as gaining the ability to call down lightning from the sky. Zinogre is only capable of enraging while charged. Damaging them enough will remove their charge. In Master Rank, Zinogre will begin the fight already partially charged.
If a Zinogre is knocked down, Fulgurbugs can be caught and gathered from their back.
If a Zinogre is caught in a Shock Trap, they proceed to eat it, immediately entering their Charged state upon escaping. Zinogre are immune to Shock Traps when charged.
Zinogre.sightings: Zinogre is found in the Shrine Ruins, Flooded Forest, the Citadel and Jungle.
Zinogre.characteristics:
Fanged wyverns whose bodies are streaked with electricity. Sharp claws and strong limbs allow them to thrive in mountainous terrain. During hunts, they gather numerous Thunderbugs to boost their power and enter a supercharged state.Characteristics: Fanged wyverns whose bodies are streaked with electricity. Sharp claws and strong limbs allow them to thrive in mountainous terrain. During hunts, they gather numerous Thunderbugs to boost their power and enter a supercharged state. In their supercharged states, Zinogre not only have different attack patterns but also become faster, hit harder, and gain immunity to Shock Traps. Staggering them, however, may knock them out of this state.
Threat Level: ★★★★★★

Apex Zinogre.hunter_notes: An angry Apex Zinogre will trigger a devastating move, causing a lightning strike upon the Thunderbugs it controls, after which it will pounce viciously on its prey. Push on against an enraged Apex to quickly rid it of its rage and steady its temper.
Apex Zinogre.characteristics: A Zinogre so mighty, it was crowned an Apex. Its body is covered in scars and wounds as if it had been caught in a storm, and it's seemingly always dominated by wrath and terror. Its forelegs - and their every strike - brim with ferocious sparks. The call of an Apex unleashes its tortured anger on nearby beasts, driving them into a frenzy.An angry Apex Zinogre will trigger a devastating move, causing a lightning strike upon the Thunderbugs it controls, after which it will pounce viciously on its prey. Push on against an enraged Apex to quickly rid it of its rage and steady its temper.

Stygian Zinogre.hunter_notes:
Stygian, much like Zinogre, also primarily attacks with their forelimbs, tail or by slamming down with their body. They are similarly adept at combo-ing their attacks together, though in different ways. They can also utilise their Dracophage Bugs, sending them off before they call down a lightning strike where they currently are.
Periodically during the fight, Stygian will begin howling into the air to call more Dracophage Bugs to their back, summoning lightning strikes around them as they do so, eventually leaping back and emitting a pulse of Dragon energy around them as they enter a charged state. In this state, most of Stygian’s physical attacks become imbued with Dragon element. Damaging them enough will remove their charge.
While charged, several of Stygian's attack will summon Dracophage lightning strikes. Periodically while charged, Stygian will leap in place as their charge intensifies, causing them to summon more lightning strikes with their attacks. Hitting a hunter with their claw spin causes them to automatically intensify their charge. Flinching them can cause this charge to weaken.
If a Stygian is knocked down, Dracophage Bugs can be caught from their back using a Capture Net.
Stygian Zinogre.sightings: Stygian Zinogre is found primarily in the Frozen region of the Guiding Lands from level 3 onwards.
Stygian Zinogre.characteristics: Has a symbiotic relationship with Dracophage Bugs, which it releases like bullets. Becomes even more dangerous when covered in light.
Stygian Zinogre.useful_information: Useful Information: Its powered-up state is cancelled when it flinches or is toppled. When its hide toughens, it becomes more vulnerable to elemental attacks.

Thunderlord Zinogre.characteristics:
Threat: ★★★★★★While a Thunderlord Zinogre broadly resembles a regular individual as far as its basic body plan is concerned, there are some drastic differences to be found beyond that. The skin has a stronger green hue compared to a regular Zinogre, and most of the fur and spikes of a Thunderlord display a regal golden color. The front limbs meanwhile have a reddish hue to them. The horns of a Thunderlord Zinogre are also asymmetrical, with the right horn being much larger and more curved than the left. The body of a Thunderlord is said to be constantly overflowing with thunder energy.[2] This can be observed in the fur, which is a glowing golden color and is known to continue expelling electricity even after it has been removed from the body.[3]
Thunderlord Zinogre can reach a level of power unseen in regular individuals, wherein their bodies become robed in golden lightning. In this so-called Ultracharged State, Thunderlord Zinogre can discharge more powerful thunderbolts.[4]
It is currently unknown how a Thunderlord Zinogre comes to be. It can be noted that it strongly resembles an Apex Zinogre, but no direct relation between the two (beyond both being variations of the Zinogre species) has thus far been discovered.
Thunderlord Zinogre.behavior:
Very little is known about the Thunderlord Zinogre's behavior. It is considered extremely aggressive and its temper is subject to folkloric tales of its anger tearing the skies apart.[4]
While Deviants are generally considered quite rare, Thunderlord Zinogre have been noted to sometimes appear in groups. While mostly solitary, they have been sighted in pairs[5] and, on at least one occasion, in a hoard of up to six individuals.[6] The origin and purpose of this behavior is entirely unknown.

Arkveld.hunter_notes:
A flying wyvern that was considered extinct according to documents left behind by the Guild. Their wings have a unique, chain-like blade that can extend and retract freely to reap their prey. They feed on elemental energy absorbed through these chainblades, and are able to convert the energy to unleash dragon element attacks.
Helpful Hints: The more energy this monster absorbs, the more ferocious its attacks become. Once they fill their energy tanks, their chainblades will sweep out to attack an even wider area. Conversely, since their wings possess organs that absorb energy, a hunter can force the energy to leak out by focusing attacks there. Flooding them with continuous elemental attacks will eventually overload the organs, forcing the monster out of its enhanced state.Arkveld primarily attacks with its chainblades, which can extend and retract at will, allowing them to be used for both slashing blade attacks and long-ranged whip strikes. It is also able to use its extendable tail to stab and sweep at targets behind it.
After some time, Arkveld will enter an enhanced state where its chainblades each split into two (for a total of four) and become charged with  Dragon energy. In this state, its chainblade attacks will cover a wider area, with certain attacks also inflicting  Dragonblight, as well as being able to plunge its chains into the ground and release Dragon bursts. However, its chainblades will become extremely weak to elemental damage instead of immune, as well as taking slightly more damage overall. Dealing enough damage to a chainblade will collapse it back into its original form, while overloading both its chainblades will dispel the enhanced form and topple the monster. Arkveld will exit this state when they exhaust, but will enter it more frequently as it nears death.
Breaking one of its Chainblade parts always drops a Crushing Chainblade Shard, which can be picked up as a Heavy Slicing or Piercing Pod.
In its enhanced state, after performing either their quadrupdal chain slam or their dragon explosions, Arkveld's chains will become a weak point for Focus Strikes. Successfully landing a Focus Strike on its chains during these windows will immediately topple it.
Arkveld.sightings: Arkveld can be found in any locale irrespective of time or weather period.
Arkveld.characteristics:
Hunters Notes: A flying wyvern that was considered extinct according to documents left behind by the Guild. Their wings have a unique, chain-like blade that can extend and retract freely to reap their prey. They feed on elemental energy absorbed through these chainblades, and are able to convert the energy to unleash dragon element attacks.
Helpful Hints: The more energy this monster absorbs, the more ferocious its attacks become. Once they fill their energy tanks, their chainblades will sweep out to attack an even wider area. Conversely, since their wings possess organs that absorb energy, a hunter can force the energy to leak out by focusing attacks there. Flooding them with continuous elemental attacks will eventually overload the organs, forcing the monster out of its enhanced state.Arkveld is a large quadrupedal Flying Wyvern that is covered in tough gray scales and snow-white furs. The scales are noted to be extremely hard while also having fairly brittle edges.[2] The fur meanwhile consists of strong intertwining strands that create a resistant mesh, further increasing the wyvern's defenses.[3] It appears to have tridactyl forelimbs, meaning it has three claws as the fourth and fifth digits seem to have developed into its chains. The hindlegs are zygodactyl with two toes in front and two rear, much like Seregios. Arkveld also has two facial protrusions that greatly resemble tusks, and has an upward cone-shaped nose (the Hunter's Guild seems to call these growths "horns" for the moment[4]). The creature’s back is well armored, as it is covered with white scales that acts as a second layer of armor to prevent being attacked from the back by overlapping much like human made armor[5]. A large bump protrudes from the top of its back plates, which has been noted to sometimes attract lightning strikes during the Sandtide in Windward Plains. Its tail is rather flat, flexible, and covered with rocky plates, with incredibly thick muscles hidden beneath.[6]
Arkveld's most unique aspects are the chain-like structures extending from the lower segment of its front limb, comprised of rocky plates called Calloushells layered over highly flexible sinews that glow purple when active.[7] Although initially folded into a hard blade-like structure it can use to slash opponents, they can unfold into highly flexible whips that it can freely manipulate, allowing it to strike targets from afar, grab them, or pull itself towards surfaces. These whips house unique organs that can absorb elemental energy from their environment or other monsters, which Arkveld is able convert in to Dragon element for its own use. While Arkveld is sufficiently enraged and powered up, each whip splits in two and becomes charged with Dragon energy, allowing them to create explosive chain reactions. The elemental capacity of these organs can however be overloaded, causing harm to the wyvern and forcing it to rest and recover.[8]
Arkveld is able to feed directly on its absorbed energy, although it can also eat normally. It also has an unusual ability to absorb certain traits from monsters it preys on, which is the factor that is speculated to have altered the behavior of the Guardian Arkveld. Arkveld grows mysterious gems inside of its body, which are said to absorb life - if this is related to its element-draining properties is currently unknown.[9]
Arkveld.behavior:
Arkveld often tends to its chain-like appendages, and can be seen grooming its chains with its mouth or claws. A behavior also seen in Arkveld is repeatedly rubbing and swirling its chains against the ground in an arc pattern as the sinews glow, leaving dark marks and scales on the ground, like drawing a crop circle. The intention of this action is unclear as of yet. Arkveld is highly wary of its surroundings, and often turns its head to look around as it goes about its day, even while eating. It seems nomadic in nature, can be found in any environment, and sleeps at no fixed spots in a given locale (e.g., in the Windward Plains, it can sleep in both the Doshaguma and Rey Dau nest).
It is highly aggressive towards both hunters and monsters, and if one wanders too close to Arkveld, it immediately picks a fight. It appears quite voracious, and will often immediately attempt to grapple and strangle potential prey with its chains before draining their energy. In the Ruins of Wyveria, it has been observed breaking open Guardian cocoons and devouring the dormant Guardians within.
Arkveld.useful_information: The more energy this monster absorbs, the more ferocious its attacks become. Once they fill their energy tanks, their chainblades will sweep out to attack an even wider area. Conversely, since their wings possess organs that absorb energy, a hunter can force the energy to leak out by focusing attacks there. Flooding them with continuous elemental attacks will eventually overload the organs, forcing the monster out of its enhanced state.
